definitions.definition: used in negative sentences and questions to talk about something that has not happened but that you expect to happen
definitions.sensetop: not yethave yet to do something
definitions.labels: (British English)(North American English)North American EnglishNorth American EnglishBritish EnglishBritish EnglishNorth American English(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: I haven't received a letter from him yet.
I didn't receive a letter from him yet.
‘Are you ready?’ ‘No, not yet.’
We **don't yet know** what really happened.
We have **yet to decide** what action to take *(= We have not decided what action to take)*.
Don't go yet.
We don't need to start yet.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize an increase in number or amount or the number of times something happens

examples.text: snow, snow and yet more snow
yet another diet book
Prices were cut yet again *(= once more, after many other times)*.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that something is the best, longest, etc. thing of its kind made, produced, written, etc. until now/then
definitions.sensetop: the best, longest, etc. something yet

examples.text: the most comprehensive study yet of his music
It was the tallest building yet constructed anywhere.

definitions.definition: from now until the period of time mentioned has passed

examples.text: He'll be busy for ages yet.
They won't arrive for at least two hours yet.

definitions.definition: used to say that something could, might, etc. happen in the future, even though it seems unlikely
definitions.sensetop: could, might, may, etc. do something yet

examples.text: We may win yet.
She could yet surprise us all.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize an increase in the degree of something (= how bad, important, etc. it is)

examples.text: a recent and yet more improbable theory

definitions.definition: until now or until a particular time in the past

examples.text: an as yet unpublished report
As yet little was known of the causes of the disease.

definitions.definition: used to say that while one thing is good, another thing is even better

examples.text: You can see and, better yet, hear the effects of these changes on their website.
I wanted to make my parents proud by becoming a lawyer or, better yet, a doctor.

definitions.definition: not now but probably quite soon

examples.text: I can't give you the money just yet.

definitions.definition: used to comment on something that was almost successful but in fact failed

wordOrigin: Old English gīet(a), of unknown origin.
